The described symptoms and medical history suggest that this man is experiencing recurrent episodes of syncope, specifically carotid sinus hypersensitivity (CSH), also known as carotid sinus syndrome. 

This condition is commonly seen in elderly men and can be triggered by neck movements or any stimulus that presses on the carotid sinus (such as a tight necktie). Stimulus causes increased baroreceptor firing, leading to a drop in heart rate and/or blood pressure that results in a brief loss of consciousness. These patients are typically otherwise healthy and can recover quickly without experiencing any residual effects like confusion.

Given the syncope occurred in the context of neck manipulation and the cardiopulmonary and neurologic examinations are within normal limits, it suggests a reflex-mediated (neurocardiogenic) cause, making CSH the most likely diagnosis in this patient. 

As part of diagnostic evaluation, a carotid sinus massage performed under ECG monitoring can confirm the diagnosis, but this should be done after a carotid ultrasound to rule out carotid artery stenosis (to avoid provoking a stroke). 

This man also has significant risk factors for atherosclerotic disease (age >65, male sex, tobacco use). Therefore, before performing carotid sinus massage, it would be prudent to visualize the carotid arteries (via carotid duplex) to rule out significant carotid stenosis or plaque, which would make carotid sinus massage unsafe due to risk of stroke.
